titlestmt.titleproper: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Friends and Services, Series H
A Guide to the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Friends and Services, Series H FA317

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 13:19:21 -0400.

did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Friends and Services, Series H

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in twenty subseries, as follows:

Biography; Cemeteries; Chandler and Rudd; Clubs; Dancing; Detectives; Doctors; Donations; Friends and Relations; Horses, Stables, Garages; Office; Portraits; Publicity; Taxes; Requests for Photos of Art Objects; Washington Appeals; Form Letters; Foreign Mail; Family of Alta Rockefeller Prentice; Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Friends and Services series is primarily John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s personal correspondence with his friends and relations. Other files deal with a variety of support, service, and administrative activities such as the operation of the Family Office, family membership in social clubs, family doctors, management of family garages and stables, and arrangement for the biographies of John D. Rockefeller and John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

The series contains correspondence between members of the Rockefeller family and the Family Office and friends, relatives, employees, and associates. The correspondence deals with a wide variety of topics. The family members who figure most prominently in the papers are John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller, David Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Sr., Martha Baird Rockefeller, Edith Rockefeller McCormick and members of her family, and Alta Rockefeller Prentice and members of her family.
There are twenty sections within the Friends and Services series. Each section is described individually here.

The Biography section covers the years 1894-1960. Materials in this section discuss the selection of an author and other arrangements for biographies of John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and John D. Rockefeller, Jr.
The Cemeteries section spans the years 1879-1954 and discusses the purchase of burial plots and the upkeep of grave sites.

The Chandler & Rudd section covers the years 1902-1958. Chandler & Rudd were grocers; W. C. Rudd was John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s brother-in-law. Topics covered in this section of the Friends and Services series include family loans to the firm.
The Clubs section, with documents dating from 1910 to 1961, includes materials on the family's memberships in and their support of social clubs.
The Dancing section covers the years 1914-1952; documents in this section include invitations received to dances and arrangements for orchestras for dances at 10 West 54th Street.

The Detectives section spans the years 1914-1940. Items in this section include requests for positions as private detectives, information about detectives hired to investigate impersonation of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and John D. Rockefeller 3rd (2 cases), and extortion letters (2 cases).

The Doctors section covers the years 1905-1960. This section consists of files on individual family physicians, mostly correspondence reflecting friendship between John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and family doctors. It also includes information on gifts of appreciation from John D. Rockefeller, Jr., some medical records on John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and the brothers as boys, and some bills. The entire Doctors section is closed to research.
The Donations section dates from 1894 to 1961 and includes information about small John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. donations and gifts of money, mostly to individuals.

The Friends and Relations section, which spans the years 1886-1961, is primarily composed of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s correspondence with a multitude of friends, associates, relatives, and acquaintances.

The Horses, Stables, and Garages section covers the years 1914-1961. Information in this section details the construction, management, and disposal of New York City garages, and the purchase of horses and automobiles.
The Office section, dated 1919-1961, contains information on the management of the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller. Also included in this section are some employee pension files.
The Portraits section, which spans the years 1904-1962, discusses the arrangements for portraits of 1st, 2nd, and 3rd generations.

The Publicity section dates from 1907 to 1961. Materials in this section include clipped articles, correspondence with a variety of magazines and publishing companies regarding requests for interviews, financial assistance, and appreciation for friendly editorials.

The Taxes section covers the years 1886-1961 and consists of information on real estate and income tax records for John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and John D. Rockefeller, Jr., appeals from and contributions to tax reform organizations, and payment of federal and state unemployment tax for family employees.
The Requests for Photos of Art Objects section consists of one folder and discusses Martha Baird Rockefeller's policy against allowing photographs of her art objects to be used publicly.
The Washington Appeals section, dated from 1944-1961, contains information about small gifts made to private Washington, DC organizations.
The Form Letters section, consisting of one folder, contains samples of commonly written letters and legal documents in the Family Office.
The Foreign Mail section spans the years 1907-1961 and contains financial appeals from foreign organizations and individuals.

The Family of Alta Rockefeller Prentice section, dated from 1901-1961, pertains to John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s sister, the management of her and her heirs' financial affairs by John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and the establishment and maintenance of trusts for members of the Prentice family.
The final section of this series, the Miscellaneous File, contains "a truly kaleidoscopic potpourri of odds and ends."

did.unittitle: Biography
Biography - John D. Rockefeller - Doubleday

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Frank Doubleday assigned to write John D. Rockefeller's biography; interviews; Starr J. Murphy checked manuscript. Preparation of "Reminiscences;" John D. Rockefeller corrections; publication. Oil men's comments on "Reminiscences;" publication in book form; royalties. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, Frank Doubleday.

did.unittitle: Biography - John D. Rockefeller - W. O. Inglis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ivy Lee introduction of Inglis to John D. Rockefeller via golf; Inglis hired, 1917, to collect information on John D. Rockefeller; preparation of short sketches. Inglis' ideas regarding biography. Sources of information; comments on work by Tarbell, A. Brisbane, G. E. Vincent, etc. Decision to limit publication of work; personal problems. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. gifts to Inglis; Inglis work for Nelson A. Rockefeller. Death. Correspondents include Ivy Lee, John D. Rockefeller, W. O. Inglis, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

scopecontent.p: Doctors' bills for care of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; medical expenses at birth of Abby Rockefeller Mauzé, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller. Unwillingness of some doctors to name a specific fee for services rendered. Doctors' proposals of special projects. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. appreciation for services rendered. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Miscellaneous Memos

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Doctors' bills for care of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; medical expenses at birth of Abby Rockefeller Mauzé, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Laurance S. Rockefeller. Unwillingness of some doctors to name a specific fee for services rendered. Doctors' proposals of special projects. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. appreciation for services rendered. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. Max Gerson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Proposed cure for tuberculosis; no Rockefeller support.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. John H. Kellogg

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wrote to John D. Rockefeller, Jr. about diet and care.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. Adelbert Ames, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Researcher at Dartmouth Medical School, son of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s friend, Gen. Adelbert Ames, was consulted by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. regarding John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s eye troubles and headaches. Failure of different prescriptions for glasses to reduce headaches; graphs of headache recurrence; detailed reports of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s eyes, past and present. Correspondence with Drs. Lancaster, Knapp and Wilmer. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s support of Ames' work; Ames' discouragement regarding spreading of his discoveries. Examinations of Laurance S. Rockefeller and Winthrop Rockefeller. Correspondents include Dr. Adelbert Ames, Jr., John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dr. Lancaster, Dr. Gordon H. Gliddon.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. Adelbert Ames, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Researcher at Dartmouth Medical School, son of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s friend, Gen. Adelbert Ames, was consulted by John D. Rockefeller, Jr. regarding John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s eye troubles and headaches. Failure of different prescriptions for glasses to reduce headaches; graphs of headache recurrence; detailed reports of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s eyes, past and present. Correspondence with Drs. Lancaster, Knapp and Wilmer. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s support of Ames' work; Ames' discouragement regarding spreading of his discoveries. Examinations of Laurance S. Rockefeller and Winthrop Rockefeller. Correspondents include Dr. Adelbert Ames, Jr., John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dr. Lancaster, Dr. Gordon H. Gliddon.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. H. T. Chickering

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. sent friends and employees to Chickering for medical advice. Letter from World War I veteran who was cured of foot infection by Carrel-Dekin solution. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. frequently paid for doctor's services to others. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. William B. Coley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A specialist on cancer, friend of John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s marriage gift to Coley's son; gift to Dr. Coley. Dr. Coley's death; John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s gifts to widow. Correspondence with Coley's daughter. Correspondents include Mrs. W. B. Nauts, Dr. William Coley, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. John Dane

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Treated John D. Rockefeller, Jr. headaches and shoulder trouble with osteopathy. Visits to Dane home; personal friendship; Dr. Dane's death. Search for a new osteopath. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dr. and Mrs. John Dane.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. Theodore Dunham

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rockefeller family physician and close personal friend of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Gifts to him of money and car. Deaths of Dr. and Mrs. Dunham. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Theodore Dunham.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. Ernest Krug

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Eye, ear, nose and throat man - primarily John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s doctor. John D. Rockefeller, Sr. gift to him; Krug projects regarding medical education. Dr. Krug's death. Correspondents include Willard S. Richardson, Dr. R. Pearce, Dr. Krug.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. Robert H. Morris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Orthopedist, treated John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller for knee and foot trouble, also a stiff arm. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. John H. Richards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s general physician - had attended John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s Bible Class, was John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s personal friend. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s annual gifts to Richards, financing of his trip to Williamsburg, buying of Richards' house and letting Richards use it free. Helped him set up trust for himself and children. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Dr. J. Richards, Thomas M. Debevoise, Robert W. Gumbel.

did.unittitle: Doctors - Dr. William D. Tracy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dentist, treated John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s family. Confusion over removal of wrong tooth for Winthrop Rockefeller. Dr. Tracy's death; switch to Dr. Robertson. Gifts to Dr. Robertson and his staff. Correspondents include Dr. Tracy, Dr. Robertson, Miss Van Houten, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

Donations - Congressional Institutions - Frank Hanser (John D. Rockefeller, Sr.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Summary of gifts to congregational institutions during "tainted money" scandal. Loan for hospitalization, not repaid.

Friends and Relations - McCormick, Edith Rockefeller - John D. Rockefeller Deed of Trust - Equitable Suit - A. Oser

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Over proper distribution of stock dividends paid to Trust - Edith wanted them to be considered income; children and trustees want them considered principal - trustees tried to stay neutral. Settled out of court through compromise at John D. Rockefeller, Sr.'s suggestions; John D. Rockefeller, Sr. paid legal fees. Anita Oser, a co-plaintiff, represented by Harold McCormick. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.-Thomas M. Debevoise correspondence - plans for compromising suit. Printed briefs of Anita Oser's case in suit.

did.unittitle: Friends and Relations - Royden, Maud

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Famous English woman preacher. Efforts to promote peace and understanding during her lifetime; work during two World Wars. Asking John D. Rockefeller, Jr. for financial aid for her projects. Personal acquaintance of John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and wife. Introduces: Alec Miller, sculptor; Mr. MacMillan, lecturer; Dr. Jane Walker, pioneer medical woman.

did.unittitle: Friends and Relations - Scott, Albert L.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: President, Lockwood Greene Engineers, Incorporated. Led Missionary and liquor studies for John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Foreign Mission Survey. Former President of Rockefeller Center, Incorporated. Riverside Church - President of the Board of Trustees.

did.unittitle: Friends and Relations - Sims, Mr. and Mrs. H. D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Sims married Miss Rudd - her father George Rudd was John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s uncle's brother. Mr. Sims served in a secretarial capacity with John D. Rockefeller, Sr. and John D. Rockefeller, Jr. He went into Chandler and Rudd in Cleveland with his father-in-law. Financial aid to Chandler and Rudd. Personal gifts to Mr. and Mrs. Sims. Death of Mr. Sims.

did.unittitle: Friends and Relations - Sked, Caroline

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: For 50 years public school educator in Cleveland. Treasurer of Baptist Home. Active worker in the Euclid Avenue Baptist Church. Personal friend of Laura Spelman Rockefeller - established Trust Fund for Miss Sked. Death.

did.unittitle: Friends and Relations - Sleicher, John A.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Editor of Leslie's Weekly, newspaper. President of Leslie-Judge Company of New York, publishing. Served on Civil Service Commission of New York State. Matters of public concern that might interest John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Published some articles on John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and his activities. Death.

Office - National Records Management Council - Archives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Robert W. Gumbel memo regarding proposed archives; Robert Schiff, of National Records Management Council (NRMC), report regarding Rockefeller papers, recommendations. Cooperation with Colonial Williamsburg archivist; his and Kenneth Chorley's recommendations, Raymond B. Fosdick's agreement. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. discussion with sons regarding retaining NRMC, considering archives. Regarding Emmett Leahy's resignation from NRMC. Notes on Lucy Greene's paper. 1954 NRMC Summary Report. Hiring of office archivist; his memos. Correspondents include Lester J. Cappon, Kenneth Chorley, Raymond B. Fosdick, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Robert Shiff, J. W. Ernst, Nelson A. Rockefeller.

Office - Acknowledgements of Books Sent to Office
Portraits
Portraits - John D. Rockefeller - John S. Sargent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Negotiations between John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and Sargent regarding possible portrait of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.; terms. First portrait painted in Florida, March 1917; second painted at Pocantico, June 1917; Sargent's refusal to paint Abby Aldrich Rockefeller. Copies by Beckwith and James; copies sent to New York Chamber of Commerce, Cleveland Chamber of Commerce, University of Chicago, and Peking Union Medical College. Loaning of portraits to museums. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller, Sr., John S. Sargent, Welles Bosworth.

Portraits - John D. Rockefeller Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Making of stell engraving copies of John D. Rockefeller, Sr. photograph; permission to publish photo. Distribution of autographed photos; requests from artists who want to do John D. Rockefeller, Sr. portrait, declined. Photos of various paintings of John D. Rockefeller, Sr.; refusal to allow family photo used for advertising purposes; offers of John D. Rockefeller, Sr. photos and paintings to John D. Rockefeller, Jr., declined. Orders for photos. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Robert W. Gumbel.

did.unittitle: Publicity - Air Affairs, Incorporated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reports on proposed cultural and philosophical aviation publication; Laurance S. Rockefeller became trustee; Nelson A. Rockefeller contribution; memberships lists, printed reports. Laurance S. Rockefeller and other trustees resigned over disagreement with President Bill Partridge regarding finances; change of organization's name to American Society of Air Affairs. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Arthur W. Packard, William Partridge, Bill Borden.

did.unittitle: Publicity - Christianity and Crisis

did.unittitle: Publicity - Colliers Weekly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: R. H. Davis article on Belgian Congo stated John D. Rockefeller, Jr. invested in rubber concern with King Leopold and Aldrich; John D. Rockefeller, Jr. denied it, magazine printed retraction. Requests for interviews declined. Writing of "My Father Never Said Don't"; proposed Quentin Reynolds story. A. P. Sloan's article "Big Business Must Help Our Colleges." Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., P. H. Davis, Starr J. Murphy, Frederick T. Gates, Ivy Lee, Frank Jamieson.

did.unittitle: Publicity - The Churchman Associates

did.unittitle: Publicity - United States Daily

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Daily aiming at class circulation rather than mass appeal. 1927 John D. Rockefeller, Jr. contribution of $100,000 to send paper to schools and city officials on three month free trial subscription. Bought bonds through Robert W. Gumbel. Declined 1932 request for aid. Paper became weekly, U.S. News. Nelson A. Rockefeller interest in David Lawrence. Correspondents include David Lawrence, Raymond B. Fosdick, Thomas B. Appleget, Robert W. Gumbel, Arthur W. Packard.
